inference:
Solution:

The area of an equilateral triangle with side length $s$ is $\frac{\sqrt{3}}{4}s^2$.  The area of the entire star is the area of six equilateral triangles with side length 3 minus the area of the central hexagon. The area of each equilateral triangle is $\frac{\sqrt{3}}{4}(3^2)=\frac{9\sqrt{3}}{4}$ square units. The central hexagon can be divided into six equilateral triangles with side length 1.5.  The area of each of these triangles is $\frac{\sqrt{3}}{4}(1.5^2)=\frac{9\sqrt{3}}{16}$ square units. Therefore, the area of the hexagon is $6\cdot\frac{9\sqrt{3}}{16}=\frac{27\sqrt{3}}{8}$ square units.  So, the area of the star is $6\cdot\frac{9\sqrt{3}}{4}-\frac{27\sqrt{3}}{8}=\frac{108\sqrt{3}}{8}-\frac{27\sqrt{3}}{8}=\boxed{\frac{81\sqrt{3}}{8}}$ square units.
